Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CPS: Designing Complex Cyber-Physical Systems for Failure Resilience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on developing a novel design platform to improve failure-resilience in complex cyberphysical systems (CPSs) by exploiting the synergy between the design and operation of the physical systems. Resilience defines the ability of an engineered system to sense and withstand adverse events, and to recover from the effects of the adverse events. The design platform provides new methods and tools needed to leverage cyber-enabled failure prognostics and prognostics-informed failure recovery for making CPSs resilient with reduced levels of redundancy. This project will develop the methods and tools, and demonstrate proof-of-concept of the design platform using wind turbine gearbox as a CPS application. The success of this research will produce major advancements in extending life and durability of CPSs, and will potentially lead to the development of CPSs that are more reliable and cost-effective than existing systems. The design platform will also enhance the understanding and design of resilient cyber-physical infrastructure systems that provide essential goods and services despite adverse events.

To date, failure prognostics of a physical system has been exploited only in the operation stage and in isolation with the early design of the system, which may be attributed to the lack of cognizance of strategic interactions between the design and operation of the system. The design platform developed in this project will bridge the gap between early-stage design and post-design prognostics by facilitating a synergistic integration of simulation-based design and sensor-based prognostics. The research project will provide rich research and educational experiences for graduate students in the fields of engineering design, embedded monitoring systems and prognostics and health management, as well as offer unique education and outreach programs for undergraduate and high school students in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to create a new design platform to improve failure resilience of complex cyber-physical systems (CPSs) by exploiting the synergy between the design and operation of the physical systems. Resilience defines the ability of an engineered system to sense and withstand adverse events, and to recover from the effects of the adverse events. The design platform provides new methods and tools needed to leverage cyber-enabled failure prognostics and prognostics-informed failure recovery (via just-in-time maintenance) for making CPSs failure resilient. Our creation of the design platform at Iowa State University consisted of two tasks: (1) building a “cheap-to-evaluate” metamodel to replace an expensive design model for efficient reliability analysis and model updating; and (2) developing robust prognostics solutions that ensure accurate failure predictions across different cyber-physical applications. This project has produced the following key results.

 

- We developed a new method to perform efficient reliability analysis with physical-system design models that are high-dimensional (i.e., number of dimensions N ≥ 15), highly nonlinear, and computationally expensive (e.g., hours of runtime for one model simulation). This new reliability analysis method has great potential to enable the simulation-based design of physical systems under high-dimensional uncertainty, which is a notoriously difficult problem. Additionally, we extended the new reliability analysis method to perform efficient design optimization that considers reliability as a design constraint.

- We attempted the applications of a metamodeling technique to build and update, in (close to) real-time, models of unidirectional and additive strain maps for large-area structural systems. We improved the accuracy and robustness in the real-time reconstruction of strain map models over state-of-the-art methods. Our applications contributed to the science of structural health monitoring by being the first studies that investigate the use of the metamodeling technique to build strain maps from measurements of unidirectional and additive strains by dense sensor networks.

- We designed and implemented a physics-based deep learning method for fault diagnostics of rolling element bearings. We showed with two experimental studies that the incorporation of physical knowledge about bearing faults and their characteristics can significantly improve the diagnostic accuracy and robustness over purely data-driven machine learning methods.

- We designed and implemented a new ensemble prognostics method that assigns degradation-dependent weights to multiple prognostics algorithms. We demonstrated with two case studies that the new method can substantially improve prognostic accuracy and robustness over the existing ensemble prognostics method.

 

Broad impacts of the project are the following. (i) The reliability analysis and design methods developed in this research have the potential to accelerate the design of high-dimensional physical systems, thereby reducing the development cost of such systems. (ii) The physics-based deep learning method will potentially increase the practical adoption of predictive maintenance by machinery manufacturers and end users. This increased adoption will contribute to enhancing the resilience of cyber-physical production and service systems. (iii) Involving two Ph.D. students and a number of undergraduate students in the research helped improve their research skills and enrich their experience in a wide range of areas including metamodeling, reliability analysis, signal processing, and machine learning. (iv) The results of this project were actively shared with other researchers and industry partners through conference presentations, short courses, and invited discussions.
